questions.text: What is the half-life of digoxin?
questions.solution:
The plasma half-life of digoxin is around 40 hours (36-40 hours).

  Digitoxin  Digoxin 
Oral absorption  Very good (90-100%)  Good (60-80%)  
Plasma protein binding   95%(t1/2 5-7 days)  25%(t1/2 40 hrs) 
Elimination  Hepatic metabolism  Renal excretion (by glomerular filtration) 
Dose adjustment in  Liver failure  Kidney failure 

Therapeutic levels of digoxin in the range of 0.5-0.8 ng/ml are beneficial. An increase in levels >1.2 ng/mL is associated with increased mortality.

questions.text: Which of the following is an aromatase inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Exemestane is an aromatase inhibitor.

Estrogen is locally produced from androgen by the action of the aromatase enzyme. Locally synthesized estrogens play an important role in the development of breast cancer because they are estrogen-dependent for proliferation.

Aromatase inhibitors decrease estrogen synthesis and are widely used now in the treatment of breast cancer in postmenopausal women.

Aromatase inhibitors are:

  • Letrozole
  • Anastrozole
  • Exemestane (Irreversible inhibitor)

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presented to the ER with an acute attack of migraine. You decide to administer a long-acting triptan. Which among the following do you choose?
questions.solution:
Frovatriptan is a long-acting triptan among other triptans.

Headache recurrences in an attack are less with longer-acting triptans like frovatriptan and naratriptan but onset of action may be slow.

Related Pearl: Triptans - 5HT 1B/1D agonists

Few important properties of triptans:

  • Longest acting triptan: Frovatriptan
  • Fastest (Oral) acting triptan: Rizatriptan
  • Least bioavailability (Oral): Sumatriptan

questions.text: Which of the following drug does not act by inhibiting a transporter?
questions.solution:
Acetazolamide is a noncompetitive inhibitor of carbonic anhydrase enzyme and does not inhibit transporter.

  • Tiagabine: inhibits GABA transporter GAT1 (option a)
  • Probenecid: inhibits organic anion transporter (option b)
  • Reserpine: inhibits vesicular monoamine transporter (option d)

questions.text: The shortest acting calcium channel blocker is _______.
questions.solution:
• Clevidipine is a novel dihydropyridine available only for intravenous administration.
  • It has a very rapid onset of action (2–4 min) and a very short half-life (1–2 min).
  • It is metabolized by esterases in blood.
  • It is primarily indicated in the acute management of hypertension.

questions.text: A 23-year-old lady presented to the gynecology OPD with complaints of amenorrhea and milky discharge from her breasts. Her urine pregnancy test is negative and her serum prolactin level is 175 µg/L. The resident prescribes a long-acting D2 agonist. Which of the following drugs is she likely to have been prescribed?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario depicts hyperprolactinemia. Cabergoline is a long-acting D2 agonist.

Its t1/2 is >60 hours. It is indicated for the treatment of hyperprolactinemia and acromegaly.

Bromocriptine, lisuride, and apomorphine are short-acting when compared with cabergoline.

Bromocriptine is an ergot alkaloid derivative used in the management of type 2 diabetes mellitus, hyperprolactinemia, acromegaly, and Parkinson's disease. Cabergoline is preferred over bromocriptine for hyperprolactinemia due to lower adverse effects such as nausea and also due to dosing advantage (twice a week instead of daily dosing).

Lisuride is indicated in early Parkinson's disease but is also known to decrease prolactin levels and prevent migraine attacks. Apomorphine is a morphine derivative used to treat hypomobile "off" episodes of advanced Parkinson's disease.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs has increased absorption with food?
questions.solution:
• Oral absorption of griseofulvin is erratic because of low water solubility. Absorption is increased by administering with fatty food and by micro fining the drug particles. Ultramicrofine preparations with better absorption profile are now available.
  • Drugs in which the absorption is enhanced by food (mainly fatty food)
    • Lumefantrine
    • Griseofulvin
    • Carbamazepine
    • Chloroquine
    • Riboflavin
    • Spironolactone

questions.text: Bone resorption is enhanced by____
questions.solution:
• PGE2 acts via EP4 receptors to increase bone turnover that is both stimulations of bone resorption and formation.
  • Prostaglandins especially PGE2 may be involved in fracture healing. EP4 deletion or NSAID use in experimental animals is associated with impaired fracture healing.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is associated with coronary steal phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Coronary steal phenomenon is seen with dipyridamole.

In patients with partial obstruction of coronary vasculature, a region of ischemia develops in the myocardium. In the absence of drugs, arterioles in the ischemic areas are usually maximally dilated as a result of local compensatory mechanisms. 

When dipyridamole is administered, it acts as a nonselective arteriolar dilator. It can only dilate the vessels of the normal myocardium as the vessels of the ischemic myocardium are already maximally dilated. This diverts (steals) the blood away from the ischemic myocardium towards the normal myocardium. This is termed as coronary steal phenomenon.

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for type IIa and IIb hyperlipoproteinemias?
questions.solution:
The drugs of choice for type IIa and IIb hyperlipoproteinemias are statins. 

In type IIa or IIb hyperlipoproteinemias, there is increased LDL cholesterol with +/- increase in TG.  Statins have the maximum LDL lowering property among the hypolipidemic drugs. Therefore, they are the drugs of choice in this case.

In type III/IV hyperlipoproteinemias, there is mainly an increase in triglyceride(TG) level. Fibrates reduce the TGs contained in VLDL and increase the HDL. So they are the drugs of choice for these conditions.

Related Pearl: Familial Dyslipidemias

Type Increased levels  Manifestation
1. Hyperchylomicronemia(type I hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons, VLDL, TG  Pancreatitis, hepatosplenomegaly, and xanthomas
2. Familial hypercholesterolemia(type II hyperlipoproteinemia) LDL and cholesterol Atherosclerosis and xanthomas
3. Dysbetalipoproteinemia(type III hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons and VLDL Atherosclerosis and xanthomas
4. Hypertriglyceridemia(type IV hyperlipoproteinemia) VLDL and TG Pancreatitis

questions.text: Which of the following drugs does not produce oculogyric crisis?
questions.solution:
The oculogyric crisis is a severe manifestation of acute dystonia that is an acute side effect of drugs blocking D2 receptors. Atropine is an antimuscarinic with no effect on D2 receptors.

Options A, C, and D: Trifluoperazine, prochlorperazine, and perphenazine are typical antipsychotics with D2 antagonistic action that can cause the oculogyric crisis.

questions.text: Which of the following receptors is a ligand-gated ion channel?
questions.solution:
The 5-HT3 receptor is a ligand-gated ion channel receptor. It rapidly depolarizes nerve endings by opening the cation channels located within the receptor.

The 5-HT3 receptors are located in the GI tract (vagal & splanchnic afferents) and the brain (nucleus tractus solitarius & area postrema) and are involved in the emetic response. Hence 5-HT3 receptor antagonists like ondansetron, dolasetron etc are used as antiemetics.

All other 5-HT receptors are G-protein-coupled receptors.

questions.text: Which of the following have cytoplasmic receptors?
questions.solution:
The receptors of cortisol are intracellular (cytoplasmic or nuclear) soluble proteins.

 

Related Pearl: Mechanisms of Action of Hormones

Types of hormone receptors
Hormones that bind to intracellular receptors
Cytoplasmic receptors Glucocorticoids
Mineralocorticoids
Androgens
  Vitamin D
Nuclear receptors Thyroid hormones
Vitamins A
Hormones that bind to cell surface receptors
1. G-protein coupled receptors (GPCR)
Gs: stimulation of second messenger cAMP ACTH, CRH
TSH, GHRH
FSH, LH, hCG
Vasopressin (V2 receptors)
Catecholamines (β receptors)
Somatostatin
Glucagon
Secretin
Parathyroid hormone
Gi: inhibition of second messenger cAMP Catecholamines (ɑ2 receptors)
Acetylcholine (M2, M4)
Somatostatin

Gq: second messenger is phospholipase C or cGMP

 Phospholipase C (IP3 DAG pathway):
GnRH, GHRH, TRH
Catecholamines (ɑ1 receptors)
Vasopressin (V1 receptor)
Gastrin
Cholecystokinin
Oxytocin
Acetylcholine (M1, M3, M5)
cGMP:
Atrial natriuretic peptide
Nitric oxide
2. Tyrosine kinase receptors
Through the JAK-STAT (non-receptor tyrosine kinase) or MAP kinase (receptor tyrosine kinase) pathway  Growth factors like IGF, VEGF, FGF, PDGF
Growth hormone
Erythropoietin
Insulin
Prolactin


Notes:
1. Even though the cytoplasmic receptors are present in the cytoplasm, once the hormone-receptor complex is formed it moves to the nucleus for its actions.

2. Vitamin D is a cytoplasmic receptor. All intracellular receptors are inherently nuclear receptors as they bind and get activated at the nucleus as mentioned above but they have two sites of primary action- cytoplasm and nucleus. 

3. While receptor tyrosine kinases have intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity, non-receptor tyrosine kinases have an external tyrosine kinase component that interacts with the receptor as and when required.

questions.text: Bromocriptine’s primary mechanism of action in the treatment of type 2 diabetes is______
questions.solution:
• In type 2 diabetes, patients have low hypothalamic dopaminergic activity in morning. This results in higher sympathetic tone and increased blood glucose levels.
  • Bromocriptine acts as a sympatholytic dopamine agonist and improves glycemic control.

Note: 

  • Effects of sympatholytic action of bromocriptine 
    • Decreased hepatic glucose production 
    • Decrease in insulin resitance (option A)
    • Decrease in plasma FFA (Free fatty acids)/TG  
  • Remember: The formulation approved for type 2 diabetes is a quick release low dose formulation different from those, which are used for other indications. It is administered within 2 hours of awakening in type 2 diabetes patients.

questions.text: A patient who is on levodopa therapy presents with confusion, delusions of grandeur, and hallucinations. What is the most appropriate treatment for his condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of levodopa-induced psychosis for which quetiapine is the most appropriate treatment.

Quetiapine and clozapine are the two atypical antipsychotics that are most effective and best tolerated in levodopa-induced psychosis. 

Typical antipsychotics are effective against levodopa-induced psychosis but may cause marked worsening of parkinsonism. Hence, atypical antipsychotics are deemed safer.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is high dose methotrexate indicated in?
questions.solution: High-dose methotrexate with leucovorin rescue (HDM-L) is a standard agent for adjuvant therapy of osteosarcoma. HDM is critical in the management of childhood acute lymphocytic leukemia (ALL). HDM-L also produces a high response rate in CNS lymphomas.

questions.text: A 53-year-old hypertensive patient has been on ACE inhibitors for the last 12 years. Which of the following effects would you expect to see in this patient?

choices.text: Rightward shift in renal pressure natriuresis curve
Decrease in compliance of large arteries

questions.solution:
ACE inhibitors, when used for a long time in patients with hypertension, cause a reduction in filtration fraction.

Filtration fraction is the ratio of GFR to that of renal plasma flow. ACE inhibitors increase renal blood flow without altering GFR and thus result in reduction of filtration fraction.

Option A: The graph plotted between urinary sodium excretion and mean blood pressure is known as the pressure natriuresis curve. For example, when dietary sodium intake is low, renin release is stimulated. Angiotensin II acts on the kidneys to shift the renal pressure – natriuresis curve to the right. This increases sodium and water retention. 

Conversely, when dietary Na+ is high or when ACE inhibitors are used, there is the withdrawal of angiotensin II. The renal pressure natriuresis curve shifts to the left.

The following image depicts a pressure natriuresis curve:

Options C and D: ACE inhibitors do not cause a significant increase in heart rate and can have a favorable change in the compliance of large arteries on long-term use.

questions.text: “Proof of concept” for a new drug is generally proven in which phase of a clinical trial?
questions.solution:
“Proof of concept” for a new drug is generally proven in phase II of a clinical trial.

Phase II of clinical trials

  • It involves a small group of patients (50-500).
  • Most of the new drugs will be administered for the first time in patients with the target disease.
  • The study is designed to obtain "Proof of concept"(Potential of the drug to treat the disease) and dose-ranging study (provides input for choosing the most appropriate dose for phase III studies).

 

Related Pearl: Phases of Clinical Trials

Phase I

(First in human)

Phase II

(First in patient)

Phase III

(Multi-site trial)

Phase IV

(Post-marketing)

10 – 100 

50 - 500 

500 - 3000

Large or according to study

Usually healthy volunteers

Patients with the target disease

Patients with the target disease

Real-world patients

Open-label study

Randomized and controlled trial; may be blinded

Randomized and controlled trial; may be blinded

Usually the observational or open-label

Human pharmacology and safety: To determine safety, tolerability and pharmacokinetic parameters

Therapeutic exploration and dose-ranging: To determine efficacy and dose-ranging

 

Therapeutic confirmation and comparison: Indications are finalized and guidelines for therapeutic use are formulated. Monitoring of adverse reactions is done. 

Postmarketing surveillance: To monitor drug interactions, compliance and long-term or rare side effects

Extends from months to 1 year

1–2 years

3–5 years

Unending, after drug approval

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding aspirin?

choices.text: Acidification of urine helps in its excretion.
It is an organic acid with pKa of 3.5.

questions.solution:
Acidification of urine does not help in the excretion of aspirin.

Aspirin and salicylates are acidic in nature. Alkalinization of the urine increases the rate of excretion of aspirin as the ionised form of aspirin increases which is not reabsorbed from the tubular fluid in the kidney. 

Option A- Around 80-90% of salicylates are bound to plasma proteins especially albumin. 

Option D- Aspirin (acetylsalicylic acid) has a pKa of 3.5.

questions.text: In which of the following patients is transdermal selegiline approved for use?
questions.solution:
Selegiline transdermal patch is approved for depression. The transdermal patch provides the high concentration required for antidepressant action. At higher doses, MAO-A is also inhibited and is highly effective in depression. 

Selegiline is a selective MAO-B inhibitor at low doses. It is used in Parkinson's disease at low doses, administered orally.

questions.text: A patient developed thyroid storm in the post-operative ward and was immediately started on IV propranolol and a loading dose of propylthiouracil. The antithyroid drug acts by inhibiting which of the following deiodinases?
questions.solution:
Propylthiouracil inhibits only type I deiodinase (D1).

Deiodinases are the enzymes that are involved in the peripheral conversion of T4 to either T3 or reverse T3. Type I deiodinase (D1) and type II deiodinase (D2) convert T4 to T3. Type III (D3) is involved in the conversion of T4 to reverse T3. 

Note: Amiodarone inhibits both types I and type II deiodinases.

questions.text: A 45-year-old lady, diagnosed with breast cancer, is started on a selective estrogen receptor modulator. Identify the drug.
questions.solution:
Raloxifene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator. 

It has agonist action on bone and antagonist action on the breast and uterus.

It is used in the treatment and prevention of osteoporosis and in breast cancer prevention in high-risk postmenopausal women.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about ketorolac?

choices.text: It's analgesic action is equal to morphine in post-operative pain
It is used as a pre anaesthetic medication

questions.solution:
Analgesic action of ketorolac is equal to morphine in post-operative pain

Ketorolac, an NSAID is an aryl acetic acid derivative with the following properties

  • It has mild anti-inflammatory action but is a potent analgesic (Option A). In postoperative pain reduction, the efficacy of ketorolac is comparable to morphine. Many studies have concluded that the analgesic action of ketorolac is equivalent to morphine. 
  • It does not interact with the opioid receptors and is therefore free of the opioid side effects (Option D)
  • It is mainly used in postoperative pain relief (Option C)

questions.text: Which among the following antihistaminic drugs has additional platelet-activating factor antagonistic property?
questions.solution:
Rupatadine is an antihistaminic drug that has additional platelet activating factor antagonistic property and is indicated in allergic rhinitis.

Platelet-activating factor (PAF) is involved in the pathophysiology of allergic rhinitis, asthma, and anaphylaxis.

questions.text: Which of the following does not belong to class 1A antiarrhythmics?
questions.solution:
• Propafenone belongs to class IC antiarrhythmics.
  • Class 1A antiarrhythmics are quinidine, procainamide, disopyramide.

Related Pearl: Anti-arrhythmic drugs

Class of antiarrhythmic drugs 

 

Mechanism of action

Effect on action potential duration

Class I

    

Class IA

Procainamide

Quinidine

Disopyramide

 

Na+ channel blockers with significant K+ channel blocking property

 

Prolonged

Lidocaine

Mexiletine

 Na+ channel blockers with K+ channel opening property 

Shortened or no effect

Flecainide

Propafenone

Moricizine

 Na+ channel blockers with negligible K+ channel blocking property 

Variable or no effect

Esmolol

 β- blockers -

questions.text: Which of the following is not a prodrug?
questions.solution:
Ticagrelor is not a prodrug and does not require metabolic activation to exert its antiplatelet action.

It is an orally active, reversible antagonist of P2Y12 subtype of ADP receptors. Since the drug does not require hepatic activation, it can be used in patients with CYP2C19 mutations. Ticagrelor is metabolized into another active metabolite by CYP3A4 and is finally excreted in the urine.

Clopidogrel, prasugrel, and ticlopidine are irreversible antagonists of P2Y12 and are prodrugs requiring metabolic activation.

Related Pearl: Classification of anti-platelet drugs

Class Drugs
Cyclooxygenase- I inhibitors Aspirin
Irreversible P2Y12 inhibitors

Ticlopidine, Clopidogrel, Prasugrel
Reversible P2Y12 inhibitors Ticagrelor, Cangrelor
GpIIb/IIIa inhibitors Abciximab, Eptifibatide, Tirofiban
Thrombin (PAR-1) receptor antagonist Vorapaxar 
Phosphodiesterase inhibitors

Dipyridamole

questions.text: A middle-aged man came to the casualty with complaints of abdominal pain. On examination, it is noted that the pain radiates from the loin to the groin of the patient. The resident wants to administer a drug to the patient for symptomatic relief. Which drug is not effective in this condition?
questions.solution:
Abdominal pain radiating from loin to groin is suggestive of renal colic. Nitrates are not effective in renal colic. 

In renal colic, NSAIDs, and morphine are used for acute pain relief. Due to the short time of action of nitrates, their clinical efficacy as relaxants in genitourinary system is quite low.

Therapeutic Uses of nitrates are:

  • Angina pectoris
  • Acute coronary syndrome
  • Myocardial infarction
  • CHF
  • Biliary colic
  • Esophageal spasm

questions.text: A pregnant woman came for routine antenatal screening. During prenatal testing, the fetus was suspected to have congenital adrenal hyperplasia. What is the drug of choice for treating the fetus in-utero?
questions.solution:
The drug of choice for treating the fetus in-utero when suspected of having congenital adrenal hyperplasia is dexamethasone.

Dexamethasone readily crosses the placenta and suppresses the secretion of steroids and androgens by fetal adrenal glands. If started by 6 weeks of gestation, it reduces the virilization of external genitalia in affected females.

Chorionic villus biopsy is then performed to determine the sex and the genotype of the fetus and therapy is only continued if the fetus is an affected female.

This is not widely accepted currently due to insufficient data on long-term risks especially in unaffected females and males who derive no benefit from the treatment.

questions.text: Most rapid acting PDE-5 inhibitor is____
questions.solution:
• Avanafil is having rapid onset of action of around 15-30 minutes.
  • Clinical correlate
  • Timing of administration before sexual activity of PDE-5 inhibitors depends upon their onset of action
    • Avanafil: 15-30 minutes
    • Vardenafil: 1 hour
    • Sildenafil: 1 hour
    • Tadalafil: can be given at any time because of long duration of action (low dose)

questions.text: Which of the following is a bradykinin receptor antagonist?
questions.solution:
Icatibant is a selective bradykinin B2 receptor antagonist. It is approved for the use of hereditary angioedema. Icatibant reduces the hypotensive action of captopril indicating the role of inhibition of bradykinin breakdown in hypotensive action of captopril.

Rimonabant is a cannabinoid receptor antagonist that was used in obesity but withdrwan due to serious psychiatric adverse effects (Option A).

Moexipril is an angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitor (Option C).

Eprosartan is an antiotensin receptor blocker (Option D).

questions.text: A 43-year-old man who is a  known case of hypertension was started on a beta-blocker. Which of the following adverse effects is least likely to be seen?
questions.solution:
Sedation is least likely to be seen with beta-blockers. Beta-blockers usually cause sleep disturbances like insomnia and nightmares.

The main adverse effects of beta-blockers are:

  • Cardiovascular side effects - exacerbation of heart failure, bradyarrhythmias, cold extremities, worsening of peripheral vascular disease, Raynaud phenomenon.
  • Respiratory side effects like life-threatening bronchoconstriction can occur.
  • Neurological side effects include fatigue. insomnia, nightmares and depression.

questions.text: Sargramostim is a recombinantly engineered analogue of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Sargramostim is a recombinant human GM-CSF (Granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor).

Indications for use:

  • Autologous bone marrow transplant - reduces the duration of neutropenia
  • Cancer chemotherapy - reduces the duration of neutropenia
  • Peripheral blood stem cell collection - to mobilize CD34 positive progenitor cells

It is administered subcutaneously or by slow intravenous infusion.

questions.text: A 43-year-old lady with papillary thyroid cancer is being treated with radioactive iodine 131. What is the half-life of this isotope?
questions.solution:
The half-life of radioactive I 131 is 8 days

I131 emits both beta and gamma rays. It is used both for diagnostic and therapeutic purposes for thyroid disorders. 

I127 is the stable isotope of iodine. 

I123 is the radioactive isotope of iodine that emits only gamma rays. The action is short-lived with a half-life of around 13 hours. It is indicated for diagnostic indications only. 

Related Pearl: Half life of radio isotopes

Radioisotope Half-life
Cobalt 60 5.2 years
Iridium 192 74 days
Iodine 131 8 days
Iodine 125 60 days
Iodine 123 13 hours
Iodine 132 3 hours 
Cesium 137 30 years
Technetium 99m 6 Hours
18 FDG 110 minutes
Radon 222 3.8 days
Radium 226 1600 years
Strontium-89 50.5 days
Strontium- 90 28 years
Phosphorus 32 14 days

questions.text: Vasodilator used topically for the treatment of alopecia:
questions.solution:
Topical minoxidil is used for the treatment of androgeneticic alopecia in both male and female patients.

Mechanism of action: 

Exact mechanism is not known yet. 

  • May act at the level of hair follicle involving direct stimulation of hair follicle cells 
  • May stimulate cutaneous blood flow

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with chronic kidney disease was given a diuretic intravenously. Following administration of the drug, she developed tinnitus and diminished hearing. Which of the following drugs was most likely given?
questions.solution:
Ethacrynic acid is the diuretic that was most likely given as it is commonly associated with ototoxicity.

Ototoxicity occurs with rapid intravenous infusion and the hearing impairment and deafness are usually reversible.

Ethacrynic acid should be used only in patients who are not able to tolerate other loop diuretics.

questions.text: Maternal and fetal outcomes are worse with_______

choices.text: Similar outcomes with A, B, C

questions.solution:
• Beta 2 agonists can lead to fetal hypoxia due to decreased placental perfusion. Maternal effects like tachycardia, hypotension, and pulmonary edema can be seen. The first approved exclusive beta 2 agonist tocolytic ritodrine was voluntarily withdrawn from the market.
  • A meta-analysis has shown both calcium channel blockers and atosiban to have better maternal and fetal outcomes among tocolytics.

questions.text: What is the most potent statin?
questions.solution:
• Among the statins, PITAVASTATIN is the latest and most potent statin. Use of pitavastatin along with gemfibrozil should be avoided as the latter decreases its clearance.
  • ROSUVASTATIN has the longest t1/2 among the statins.

questions.text: Which of the following is a selective imidazoline receptor agonist?
questions.solution:
Moxonidine is a selective imidazoline (I1) receptor agonist.

It is indicated as a second line agent in the long-term management of hypertension. It also has weak alpha 2 agonist action.

Rilmenidine is another selective imidazoline receptor agonist.

Option A: Clonidine is an alpha 2 receptor partial agonist and has additional imidazoline (I1) receptor agonist action. But the main mode of action is through alpha 2 agonism.

Option B: Methyldopa does not have any action on imidazoline receptors

Option D: Brimonidine is a congener of clonidine.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with alcoholic cirrhosis develops ascites. What is the drug of choice for management?
questions.solution:
The diuretic of choice in a patient with cirrhotic ascites is spironolactone.

Spironolactone is a competitive inhibitor of the mineralocorticoid receptor in the late distal tubule and collecting duct of the kidneys. It causes a decrease in sodium reabsorption and potassium excretion in the distal tubule. As a result, spironolactone promotes sodium diuresis but maintains body potassium levels.

Spironolactone is particularly helpful in edematous states caused or exacerbated by hyperaldosteronism such as in cirrhotic ascites.

questions.text: Which of the following is a prodrug?
questions.solution:
Prednisone is a prodrug.

It is a synthetic glucocorticoid that is biologically inert until converted via hepatic metabolism (11-beta HSD1) to the active component, prednisolone.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man who is on treatment for small cell carcinoma of the lung presents with acute onset confusion, nausea, and vomiting. He appears to be euvolemic. Laboratory investigations reveal serum sodium levels to be 120 mEq/l and urine osmolality is 300 mOsm/kg . Which of the following is not used as a treatment option in his condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion (SIADH) which can occur as a paraneoplastic syndrome of small cancer of the lung. Desmopressin is not used in the treatment of SIADH.

Since excess vasopressin is the cause for SIADH, giving a vasopressin analog like desmopressin would only worsen the condition. 

Management of SIADH:

  • Fluid restriction 
  • Hypertonic saline( 3%) + loop diuretics is the treatment of choice in severe symptomatic hyponatremia.
  • Tolvaptan and conivaptan (vasopressin receptor antagonists) are preferred for long-term use.
  • Demeclocycline (a tetracycline drug) is used as an alternative.

Related Pearl: Causes of SIADH

Neoplasms

Carcinomas

  • Lung
  • Duodenum
  • Pancreas
  • Ovary
  • Bladder, ureter

Other neoplasms

  • Thymoma
  • Mesothelioma
  • Bronchial adenoma
  • Carcinoid
  • Gangliocytoma
  • Ewing’s sarcoma

Head trauma (closed and penetrating)

Infections

  • Pneumonia
  • Abscess
  • Cavitation (aspergillosis)
  • Tuberculosis
  • Meningitis, Encephalitis
  • AIDS

Vascular

  • Cerebrovascular occlusions, haemorrhage
  • Cavernous sinus thrombosis

Neurologic

  • Guillain-Barre syndrome
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Delirium tremens
  • Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis
  • Hydrocephalus
  • Psychosis
  • Peripheral neuropathy

Congenital malformations

Metabolic

  • Acute intermittent porphyria

Respiratory

  • Asthma
  • Pneumothorax
  • Positive-pressure respiration

Drugs

  • Vasopressin or desmopressin
  • Serotonin reuptake inhibitors
  • Oxytocin (high dose)
  • Vincristine
  • Carbamazepine
  • Nicotine
  • Phenothiazines
  • Cyclophosphamide
  • Tricyclic antidepressants
  • Monoamine oxidase inhibitors

questions.text: Which of the following is a correct statement regarding antiarrhythmics?

choices.text: Sotalol has additional class II action
Esmolol has additional class IV action
Propranolol has additional class I action

questions.solution:
Sotalol has both class II (beta-blocker) and class III action (K+ channel blockade). Though it is a nonselective beta-blocker, as an antiarrhythmic, it is classified under class III. 

Propranolol is a non-selective beta-blocker with additional membrane-stabilizing action especially at higher doses: Na+ channel blockade/ class I action.

Esmolol is a beta 1 selective blocker that does not have any additional class effect.

questions.text: Which of the following adverse effects is least likely in a patient who is on chronic amiodarone therapy?
questions.solution:
Nephrotoxicity is not an adverse effect of chronic amiodarone therapy. Pulmonary fibrosis associated with dry cough is the most serious side effect of chronic amiodarone therapy. It can rapidly progress and become fatal.

The side effects of amiodarone include:

  • Pulmonary fibrosis
  • Hypotension, depressed ventricular function
  • Torsades de pointes
  • Corneal microdeposits
  • Hepatotoxicity
  • Neuropathies
  • Photosensitivity
  • Thyroid dysfunction

questions.text: All of the following statements about octreotide are true except_______

choices.text: It is used in diagnostic imaging of Neuroendocrine tumors
It can be used for the management of secretory diarrhoea
It can be used in portal hypertension

questions.solution:
Octreotide is a long acting somatostatin analog. It is a peptide and ineffective orally but can be given either IM/SC/IV.

It can be used in these conditions

  • Decrease secretory diarrhea associated with neuroendocrine tumors like carcinoid and VIPoma (option c)
  • Decrease diarrhea associated with short bowel syndrome, AIDS
  • Pituitary tumors causing acromegaly (option b)
  • Islet cell tumors: to reduce hormonal secretion
  • Acute bleeding in esophageal varices seen in portal hypertension (option d)
  • GI or pancreatic fistula
  • Thyrotrope adenomas

questions.text: Maximum hepatic enzyme inhibition is seen with ______
questions.solution:
Cimetidine causes maximum hepatic enzyme inhibition among the given options.

Cimetidine inhibits CYP enzymes like CYP1A2, CYP2C9, and CYP2D6. It can interfere with the metabolism of drugs that are substrates of the above enzymes.

Ranitidine also interacts with CYP enzymes but the affinity is only 10% to that of cimetidine (Option A).

Famotidine and nizatidine are considered safer with respect to enzyme inhibition (Options C and D).

questions.text: Systemic steroids can cause all of the following except_______
questions.solution:
• Glaucoma is a side effect of prolonged topical therapy.
  • Hypertension, cataract, and osteoporosis are known side effects of systemic glucocorticoid therapy (options a, c and d).

questions.text: Topical mitomycin C is used in which of the following patients?

choices.text: A patient undergoing endoscopic treatment of angiofibroma

questions.solution:
Topical mitomycin C is used in laryngotracheal stenosis.

Mitomycin C is an antitumor antibiotic that inhibits cell division, protein synthesis and fibroblast proliferation. Topical mitomycin C has been shown to cause symptomatic improvement when applied to patients with laryngotracheal stenosis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old lady, P2L2, has been taking depot medroxy progesterone acetate as a contraceptive. Which of the following best describes the formulation?
questions.solution:
Depot medroxyprogesterone acetate (DMPA) is a long-acting progestin-only injection formulation.

DMPA is administered every 3 months intramuscularly as a contraceptive.

questions.text: Osteomalacia in phenytoin is due to:
questions.solution:
• Osteomalacia due to phenytoin use is attributed to both alteration in vitamin D and vitamin K metabolism.
  • Alteration in vitamin D metabolism and the attendant inhibition in intestinal reabsorption of Ca2+ contributes to hypocalcemia and osteomalacia.
  • The increase in vitamin K metabolism reduces the concentration of vitamin K-dependent proteins that are important for normal Ca2+ metabolism in bones. This is the reason why the osteomalacia due to phenytoin is not always ameliorated by the administration of vitamin D.
  • Gamma carboxylation of osteocalcin and other important activities in bone requires vitamin K.

questions.text: Ampicillin use in EB virus infection increases the risk of _______
questions.solution:
• Ampicillin produces a very high incidence of rashes especially in patients with AIDS and EB virus infections or lymphatic leukemia.
  • Concurrent administration of allopurinol also increases the incidence of rashes. Sometimes the rashes may be toxic in nature.
